Diese Review wird frustrierend vage. Denn Outer Wilds lebt vom Reiz des Unbekannten, der intrinsischen Neugier. Entsprechend wei√ü man am besten nicht zu viel, bevor man sich auf die Reise in dieses faszinierende Sonnensystem macht. 
Aber ein paar Dinge sind doch wichtig, denn obwohl Outer Wilds ein hervorragendes Spiel ist - es ist auch ziemlich speziell. Deshalb folgt hier ein kleines quasi spoilerfreies Briefing, bevor ihr die Triebwerke zum ersten Mal startet.

[b]Die Situation[/b]
Es ist ein gro√üer Tag f√ºr unseren Spielcharakter. Nicht nur werden wir nach abgeschlossener Pilotenausbildung heute das erste Mal ins All fliegen. Wir haben auch ein mobiles √úbersetzungsger√§t dabei, das unser Volk gerade frisch fertig entwickelt hat. Damit sollen wir die √ºberall im Sonnensystem verteilten Inschriften entziffern k√∂nnen, die eine vermutlich l√§ngst ausgestorbene Alienrasse dort hinterlassen hat. 

Lasst euch nicht vom gem√§chlichen Intro auf dem Heimatplaneten irritieren, ihr werdet schon noch lange genug durchs All zischen. Und dort dann v√∂llige Freiheit genie√üen. Keiner sagt euch, was ihr euch zuerst anschauen solltet - lasst euch einfach von eurer Neugier treiben.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3381247382
Ein bisschen Orientierung kann das Logbuch verleihen, das euch sagt, wenn ihr an einem besuchten Ort noch nicht alles entdeckt habt. Au√üerdem gibt es dort eine √úbersicht aller eurer Erkundungen, wobei Zusammenh√§nge wie bei einem Kriminalfall mit Pfeilen verbunden sind.
Trotzdem werdet ihr wahrscheinlich an den Punkt kommen, alle Planeten einmal bereist zu haben und ein bisschen auf dem Schlauch zu stehen, wie es wohl weitergeht. Doch ihr solltet nicht verzagen. Outer Wilds gelingt abseits weniger Schnitzer eine fast unsichtbare und dennoch verbl√ºffend gute Spielerf√ºhrung. Irgendwie habe ich nach etwas Herumprobieren doch fast immer etwas Neues herausgefunden - oft begleitet von einem wunderbaren "Aha"-Moment.

Diese Momente waren f√ºr mich die absoluten Highlights des Spiels. Die Mysterien und Eigenheiten dieses Sonnensystems sind so derma√üen kreativ und erwecken ein Entdeckergef√ºhl sondergleichen, wenn wir sie in ehrf√ºrchtigem Staunen St√ºck f√ºr St√ºck begreifen.

[b]Was zu beachten w√§re[/b]
Dabei sind die R√§tsel sehr organisch in die Spielwelt eingebunden - im Grunde sind die Planeten selbst und die Gesetze nach denen sie funktionieren die eigentlichen R√§tsel. Zum L√∂sen kann unsere √ºbersichtliche Anzahl an Tools n√∂tig sein. Oft m√ºssen wir aber auch einfach "nur" zur richtigen Zeit am richtigen Ort sein. Timing ist n√§mlich alles in Outer Wilds. Das Universum entwickelt sich in seiner beeindruckenden Simulation stetig weiter - bis... Ja, findet es selbst heraus. Verpassen wir den rechten Moment haben wir jedenfalls genug andere Gelegenheiten, es nochmal zu probieren.

Manchmal kann Outer Wilds dann auch etwas langatmig und repetitiv werden, wenn wir bei einem Mysterium einfach nicht mehr weiter wissen. In besonders extremen F√§llen sollte man sich meiner Meinung nach nicht daf√ºr sch√§men, mal kurz in einen Guide zu spicken. Die von einem wunderbar einpr√§gsamen, Banjo-lastigen Soundtrack untermalte Atmosph√§re des Spiels ist n√§mlich echt toll. W√§re ja schade, wenn man sich die verhagelt, weil man mit seinen stetig verzweifelter werdenden L√∂sungsversuchen konstant auf Granit bei√üt.

F√ºr die R√§tsel auch sehr hilfreich und f√ºr das Begreifen der Geschichte sogar unumg√§nglich ist ein gesunder Lesehunger. Wir finden auf unserer Reise haufenweise Inschrift-Tafeln der erw√§hnten alten Alienrasse. Die behalten immer kleine, gut geschriebene Geschichten - auch wenn sich ihr Informationsgehalt aufgrund der nicht-linearen Natur des Spiels manchmal doppelt. Diese Text-Happen sind gut verdaulich, summieren sich aber. Wer sich so gar nicht f√ºr das Lesen in Spielen begeistern kann, f√ºr den wird sich Outer Wilds wahrscheinlich stellenweise z√§h anf√ºhlen.

Es lohnt sich aber, hier dran zu bleiben. Wir entwickeln trotz den Texten als ((einzige)) Verbindung eine enge Beziehung zu der Alienrasse, lernen wie und warum diese ganzen Bauwerke im Sonnensystem entstanden sind oder √ºber die gro√üen Ziele dieses hochentwickelten Volks.

Eine letzte Anmerkung: Ich war erst verunsichert, weil das Spiel ziemlich prominent das Gamepad als Eingabeoption empfiehlt. Maus und Tastatur gehen aber auch v√∂llig klar, wie ich dann feststellte.

[i]Pers√∂nliches Rating:[/i] [b]85[/b]/100

[i]Fazit[/i]
[h3]Outer Wilds belohnt engagierte, entdeckungsfreudige Spieler mit einem sich immer in Bewegung befindlichen Sonnensystem voller faszinierender Ph√§nomene und Geheimnissen, die uns die Ehrfurcht vor dem Universum ins Gesicht zaubern![/h3] | [h1] Un juego que trasciende el tiempo y el espacio [/h1]

Seguro has visto otras rese√±as que describen a [i]Outer Wilds[/i] como un juego que se puede jugar √∫nicamente una vez, pero ¬øqu√© tiene de especial para generar ese sentimiento en tanta gente?

Una de las principales razones, y lo que lo hace tan diferente a otros juegos, es que [i]Outer Wilds[/i]  no se trata de completar niveles, hacer a tu personaje m√°s fuerte ni conseguir nuevos √≠tems. El progreso lo logras como lo har√≠as en la vida real: con conocimiento y experiencia.

[h3] ¬øC√≥mo es el gameplay? [/h3]

En [i]Outer Wilds[/i] eres un astronauta que explora un peque√±o sistema solar, mientras un bucle temporal reinicia el universo cada 22 minutos. Durante ese tiempo, se desencadenan eventos que alteran elementos clave en los diferentes planetas que puedes visitar. Sin embargo, la raz√≥n detr√°s de este bucle es un misterio para ti, solo sabes que est√° relacionado con una civilizaci√≥n alien√≠gena desaparecida, cuyas ruinas y textos antiguos est√°n esparcidos por todo el sistema solar.

Tu astronave cuenta con una computadora que guarda informaci√≥n clave y te ayuda a seguirle la pista a los principales rumores de los planetas que visitas. Mientras m√°s conocimiento recopiles, m√°s secretos se ir√°n revelando. Conectar√°s los puntos en tu mente y podr√°s resolver el misterio poco a poco, al mismo tiempo que te vuelves cada vez m√°s h√°bil en pilotar tu nave y volar con tu propulsor.

[h3] La primera regla de [i]Outer Wilds[/i]: No hables de [i]Outer Wilds[/i] [/h3]

Como seguro ya lo has deducido, este juego se disfruta al m√°ximo comenzando a jugarlo con la menor cantidad de informaci√≥n posible. Incluso el m√≠nimo spoiler podr√≠a arruinarte un puzzle o un secreto. Pero qu√©date tranquilo: todos los acertijos del juego pueden resolverse √∫nicamente con la informaci√≥n que el propio juego te proporciona.

Si te sientes atascado, no te preocupes, ve a otro planeta, explora un poco m√°s. Los planetas est√°n dise√±ados para que puedas identificar puntos de inter√©s mientras vuelas en tu astronave, [b]deja que tu curiosidad te gu√≠e[/b].

[h3] Lo que nos cautiva de este juego [/h3]

[i]Outer Wilds[/i] es un juego como ning√∫n otro, simple en sus mec√°nicas, pero que logra crear una experiencia completa. Sus misterios te atrapar√°n y despertar√°n tu curiosidad, especialmente si disfrutas indagar en el lore de los juegos. Al desentra√±ar cada parte del rompecabezas descubrir√°s las formas ingeniosas en las que el juego oculta sus secretos a plena vista.

A lo largo de tu traves√≠a, conocer√°s a un pu√±ado de personajes que, de alguna manera, estar√°n contigo en cada paso. Es este contraste entre la inmensidad del cosmos y la cercan√≠a de estos encuentros lo que hace que [i]Outer Wilds[/i] deje una huella permanente en quienes lo experimentan.

not as difficult as others make it out to be, people act like this game is super hard 100% of the time but while it can challenging this game gives you a lot of room to explore and level your character so anytime you feel like a boss is too hard you can just go explore or do one of the many side quests available and then return once your strong enough.

Call of Juarez has really great story telling and voice acting, and decent duck and cover gameplay. Mostly is it really cool game, but there are enough quirky mechanics that could hamper your experience.  The style has elements of genius that is worth playing if you can pick this up for a few dollars as it can be completed once in 10-15 hours. 

Your character narrates his role in the wild west and explains his tall tale version of what "really" happened during key events of US old West history.  It has a great comic book like style to introduce classic outlaws in an epic fashion, and the world is bright and beautiful with romanticized farmhouses, mine shafts, moving trains, and mountains.  The levels are mini areas that allow you to run within a defined arena as you hide behind structures and gun sling your way past groups of outlaws as the narrated story offers entertaining, color commentary to all the events. 

The game felt more like a shooting gallery style on rails rather than stealth strategy.  I mostly liked the ducking for cover and the shooting since your character can take some bullets yet quickly recover if you stay out of the next wave of attacks. You can pick up just a few basic pistols, rifles and shotguns to keep it interesting, and also upgrade a few power ups that allow you to carry more bullets, or to throw back incoming dynamite.  The gameplay also has an interesting dueling mode for some of the bosses where you need to increase focus meters, and out draw the enemy.  The historical nuggets that you can find on each level add a side study of the many outlaws who become the stories of the 1800's United States.  It is a great combination of tall tale and non-fiction.

As the game went on, the difficulty suddenly would ramp up and the quirks of the game became more apparent.  The enemies blend into the background making them super hard to see, yet they would easily spot you behind any barrier.  The voices of the enemies seem to come from all around and sound like they are right next to you, even when they are 50 yards away. The Q "Concentration" button helps to slow down the action and to outline your enemies but for me it would burn out so fast before I could do much. I was disappointed in the perk system as I used my points on the Silver Shotgun, Ranger Gun, and the Ornate Sawed off since they seemed like the best weapons, although as the game progressed it seemed like the regular Rifle was important to reach far enemies, and the standard Quick shooter was better for rushing enemies.   The game has a few quick events that popped up at very random times and most likely will surprise you and kill you.  When you die, sometimes the game has a tendency to place you immediately in mortal danger only to die again on the same group of enemies.  I kept dying over and over chasing a dynamite fuse that blew up in 5 sec, and I could not even see what direction I was even supposed to go.  Some of the bosses had glitches or quirks and I do not understand how I passed them besides getting a little lucky.  
For the boss Henry Plummer, I could not figure out why enemies were hitting me when I should have been safe behind a barrier. Yet somehow after many, many tries, I lucked out and he suddenly died, and I can only guess that I blew up the dynamite in his hand.   For the boss Curly Bill, he got stuck while running in place in the lumber yard so I just kept shooting him until he died.  For the boss, John Wesley Hardin, I could not figure out what the game needed me to do in the dueling event as I would draw, dodge, but the aim target would wander off. Eventually after many tries, somehow the target worked but I did not feel satisfaction that I did anything differently.

There is a lot to be loved about the style of this game, which is why I recommend playing it despite the quirks.  There is more gameplay with NewGame+ and Dueling Mode  and it may spark your curiosity to learn a bit some of the outlaws during a crazy era of US history. | [h2]üé® Graphics [/h2]

I used to play this. A lot, as you can see from the playtime. Most of the time I spent in the game was in 2022-23. I had a good group of people I played with and the servers were full of great people. We didn't really know what we were getting into, however, and eventually we all started playing less and less. Mostly because we realized that this isn't really a game. It's a job that you can pay your employer for the privilege of playing. You either pay to skip the grind or you perform ridiculous amounts of fetch quests and spam the 'G' (interact) key. I'm not kidding when I'm saying there are things that you need to do hundreds to thousands and tens of thousand times. There is an 'island soul' that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a pouch that has a less than 1% chance to drop from a mob. I don't know what the math on that works out to exactly, but googling says in the thousands of hours.

Gear 'honing' has abysmal success rates and you lose materials on every attempt. The honing materials are tiered and each level requires a different material so all your old mats are virtually worthless when you move up a tier. Drop rates for 'collection' items are extremely low and many mobs, bosses, events, and/or islands only spawn once or twice a day/week, so collection can take hundreds of hours for a single item.

Every system in the game is designed to take as much time as possible, every single day, unless you pay. Even if you pay, the time gates and drop rates stay the same, so you still have to grind. Beyond the currency bloat, there are also 4+ XP systems you need to grind.

I stopped eventually because of the sheer grindiness and utterly ridiculous currency and loot box mechanics. I came back recently because I heard some of the newer updates reduced the grind and simplified the currency. I thought I'd take a look and see whether it was worth coming back to.

I should not have. The grind is all still there and, if anything, is worse. The currency has been simplified a bit but it is still ridiculous. There is still silver, gold, crystals, royal crystals, pirate coins, open seas coins, pheons, shards, fragments, and probably others that I've just forgotten. There are six different 'profession' currencies that you have to collect and each of them has multi tiered rarities. You can convert between all of these at awful (like 10 to 1) exchange rates. There are sinks for all of them everywhere.

Despite simplifying some things, they've added whole new systems to make things even more grindy and confusing. These systems have new fetch and farm quests and use different materials that you need to use that have low drop and conversion rates. It's just more of the same.

Trying to play content from before the endgame is hit or miss because people are simply not there and the content is not accessible by just one person. You can ask in chat and you might get lucky, but there is very little incentive for an end-game character to help out with content that they probably haven't touched in years. There is a 'solo' mode option for some pre-endgame content, which can be useful, but it's a little laughable having a 'solo' mode anything in an MMO.

I could try to find a guild and try out discord to get some older, wider content done, but that doesn't solve the grind and loot box issues this game has. I don't mind grinding for an item, but grinding for just a chance at an item is a special level of hell.

There are some nice people still playing and you might be able to connect with them in game or over discord and get some things done if you are new or returning, but if you value your time, money, and sanity, don't. Pick another MMO. | Quiero aclarar que el juego en si es muy bueno, el problema es que no recomendar√≠a este juego a un jugador nuevo, ya que solo puedes jugar a este juego y disfrutarlo siendo nuevo jugador si tienes amigos que ya jueguen de antes y tengan personajes muy avanzados. Los jugadores nuevos son muy f√°cilmente identificables, siendo muy dif√≠cil que te inviten a grupos para poder realizar el contenido final del juego. Por otro lado, es un juego extremadamente exigente respecto a las horas necesarias dedicadas al d√≠a, por lo tanto, es necesaria una inversi√≥n de horas extremadamente elevada para que puedas jugar de manera aut√≥noma, pudiendo ser frustrante para muchos jugadores nuevos. | This game suffers a major struggle as one that is developed by a Korean development company and published by an American company who pushes the game updates from KR to the western version of the game. The publisher has no power or will to transform the new (or current) player experience in a meaningful, permanent way that will help them ascend to the relative power levels of veteran players.

One of the best examples: Gearing a character in this game requires collections of 'cards' for card sets which are a huge component of damage or support power for players. As such, it requires too much time commitment and/or money for new players to get to a point where they are comfortably playing endgame content with veteran players or normal consistent raid lobbies at all due to this huge missing chunk of damage or support power.

Due to the nature of raid leaders being able to inspect the full range of gear for applicants to raid lobbies, many players will be rejected because of their lack in raid power. Due to the difficulty and dps checks of some raids, the lower power players will have a hard time clearing raid content with each other at all even if they do make their own lobbies.

The developers did make content called 'solo raids' which can be completed for some of the relevant gear materials, but due to the content release schedule of the game, players are never quite able to catch up because their rate of growth is too slow.

By the time a newer player is ready to play a newer raid, most of the population will have moved on to a newer raid, and a fresh player will not have an easy time finding a raid group in the Lobby Finder that will help them learn an older raid. The older raids are referred to as 'homework', and players are often expected to already have played and farmed the raid enough by that time, so as not to hold back the players who want to complete this 'homework' raid for their needed gold.

Speaking of gold, the Western version of the game is suffering from very high economic inflation due to the rampant and seemingly unstoppable plague of gold farming bots. Korea doesn't suffer from this issue because their game client requires a Korean SSN to verify identity. Steam has no such requirements, so bot accounts can be made in mass volumes to this day.
It's against the terms of service for players to purchase gold from these bots, but they continue to do so and purchase (from the Auction House) either large volumes of honing materials or high value gear which also happens to be in high demand from the general population.

Lost Ark at its core was such a cool game and I'm happy to have played it since launch, but as of Feb2025 it's not hard to see that this game's publisher (Amazon Game Studios) and/or developers (Smilegate) continue to betray its audience at large by not acknowledging core issues at all or addressing them in a timely manner.

There are other issues I'm sure I forgot to mention, but needless to say I can't recommend this game for any new or current players at this time. | i love the game, but management is  the worst you can get in MMO.

–£—á–∏—Ç—ã–≤–∞—è —á—Ç–æ –∏–≥—Ä—É –æ—Ç–Ω–æ—Å–∏—Ç–µ–ª—å–Ω–æ —á–∞—Å—Ç–æ –æ–±–Ω–æ–≤–ª—è—é—Ç, –∂–¥—É –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ –¥–æ–±–∞–≤—è—Ç –±–æ–ª—å—à–µ –∫–∞—Ä—Ç –Ω–∞ —É—Ä–æ–Ω, –ø–∞—Ç—Ä–æ–Ω—ã –∏ —É–º–µ–Ω—å—à–µ–Ω–∏–µ —Ä–∞–∑–±—Ä–æ—Å–∞. –ò –ø–æ—á–∏–Ω–∏—Ç–µ –Ω–∞–∫–æ–Ω–µ—Ü —ç—Ç—É —Ö—Ä–µ–Ω—å –∫–æ–≥–¥–∞ —É–±–∏–≤–∞–µ—à—å —Ñ–∏–≥—É—Ä—É –ø–æ–∑–∞–¥–∏ –∫–æ—Ç–æ—Ä–æ–π —Å—Ç–æ—è–ª–∞ –¥—Ä—É–≥–∞—è –∏ —Ç–µ–±—è –≤–∞–Ω—à–æ—Ç–∏—Ç –ø–µ—Ä–º–∞–Ω–µ–Ω—Ç–Ω–æ. –ß—Ç–æ —Å–∞–º–æ–µ –∏–Ω—Ç–µ—Ä–µ—Å–Ω–æ–µ, –µ—Å–ª–∏ —É–±–∏—Ç—å –ø—Ä–µ–≥—Ä–∞–∂–¥–∞—é—â—É—é —Ñ–∏–≥—É—Ä—É –≥—Ä–∞–Ω–∞—Ç–æ–π —Ç–æ –≤–∞–Ω—à–æ—Ç –Ω–µ –ø—Ä–æ–∫–Ω–µ—Ç, –Ω–æ —è –≤–∞–º —ç—Ç–æ–≥–æ –Ω–µ –≥–æ–≤–æ—Ä–∏–ª... | This is exactly my kind of silliness. Shotgun King is a chess game except you only have your king left and he has a shotgun. If that makes you think "Wait a minute, that's not chess at all!" then you would be correct. The game only wears its chess influence only on the surface, the game actually is a turn-based strategy roguelike. You have to play through 12 rounds and defeat the final boss at the end. Each round your goal is to kill the white king. You can do this by firing your shotgun, each white piece have different amount of HP, pawns and knights have the lowest and the king has the most. Your shotgun has three main stats: firepower, range and firing arc. Firepower defines how many pellets your shotgun fires, each pellet dealing exactly one damage. Multiple pellets can hit the same target, can hit multiple targets or completely miss any target. There is some RNG involved here but the closer you stand to your target, the more likely you are to hit it. Range shows the maximum travel range of your pellets. Your firing arc shows the spread of your pellets, they will always be inside this arc. Shooting an enemy that stands directly before you will always make all pellets hit him. It's the same concept as in other shooting games, the shotgun is more powerful close range and loses its power the further you stand away. However, sometimes a wider spread might be beneficial to hit more pieces. There are some strategic decisions you can make here.
Shooting or moving will always pass your turn. White pieces will move on their turn and they can move multiple pieces at the same time. They have their own speed stat that defines how many turns they have to wait until they can move.
Moving will also reload your shotgun. This is important, so you can move outside of check and fire on your next turn.
Your shotgun has only limited ammo, which does regenerate but very slowly, so you don't want to kill every piece, you want to focus on the king but still deal with troublesome pieces.

After each floor you will come in contact with the roguelike mechanic of the game, the cards. You get a selection of two different black cards which help you for the rest of the run. These can be simple like more firepower, ammo or range but they also can give you completely new abilites like a melee attack that does not use ammo or grenades, that will hit multiple pieces but can also kill you.
Each black card is tied to a white card. These are upgrades for the white side. They can get more pieces, change how pieces move and give pieces more HP or speed. You will have to evaluate what upgrades you need but also what downsides you can endure in return. One white card that always appears is the white queen after floor 3. You can't escape her, she is everywhere.
Killing a non-pawn piece will give you an edge however. You get their "soul" which you can activate to move in the same pattern as the piece you killed. You can only store one soul but you can get black cards that allow you to store more or have some other synergy with it. These soul cards are best used to get out of check or close the distance to the white king.

The game is incredibly goofy with its concept but its also a challenging strategy game that will take you some time to master. And as you beat th egame, you will start to unlock new difficulty levels that add extra pieces at the start, improve the enemy AI and give the white king more HP. You can also unlock new shotguns that have different starting stats. There is a surprising amount of variety in this small game. The game still gets updates to this day, despite being almost three years old. It's funny, it's challening and it's the exact type of game to play at the evening after a long work day. | It was a great fun game with levels that get a little bit harder, and you can get different shotguns and after each round you pick a card that upgrades your side, and the enemy. The normal amount of turns in a round is maybe 20-30, and 9 rounds in the level and i think 8 levels. There is also endless and chase.
 | This game is a very fun strategy and roguelike game, i love the variety of cards for you and the enemy and the achievements have kept me playing for a bit now, definitely worth it for the price but would pick it up on a sale like I did. | Fun game, nice and easy but with just the right amount of strategy involved.

2 –∏–∑ 10 –ø–æ–∫–∏–Ω—É—Ç—ã—Ö —Å–µ—Ä–≤–µ—Ä–æ–≤. | ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is the ultimate test of survival where it‚Äôs not just about fighting dinosaurs‚Äîit‚Äôs about surviving in a world where everything, from the weather to the creatures to your fellow players, is out to get you. Picture this: you‚Äôre dropped into an island with nothing but your wits, some rocks, and a stick, and you‚Äôve got to figure out how to stay alive while dodging massive carnivores and attempting to avoid becoming someone else‚Äôs dinner. Add in some players who think they‚Äôre the island‚Äôs top predator (spoiler: they‚Äôre not), and suddenly, your quest to survive turns into an all-out, hilarious game of ‚Äúwho can mess with who first?‚Äù Trust me, it‚Äôs intense, but also surprisingly fun when you realize you‚Äôre a second away from being eaten by a T-Rex and you somehow make it out alive. That‚Äôs when the real fun begins!

At its heart, ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is a battle royale-style game set in a prehistoric world, filled with dangers both natural and player-made. The basic premise? You, along with other players, are dropped onto a hostile island where you must gather resources, craft weapons, tame dinosaurs, and try to survive long enough to become the last one standing. The twist? You‚Äôll need to strategize, team up, or even betray others to outsmart and outlast the competition. It‚Äôs not just about surviving the creatures; it‚Äôs about surviving the players too. Tame some raptors, build traps, create defenses, and get ready for combat because the last survivor on the island wins. Oh, and don‚Äôt forget about the giant mutant spiders and those terrifying, unkillable bosses roaming around. In short, everything wants you dead, and you have to be smarter, stronger, and faster to avoid becoming dinner.

What really stands out about ARK: The Survival of the Fittest is the blend of survival mechanics, strategy, and chaotic multiplayer action. The vast array of creatures you can tame and use in combat adds layers of complexity to the gameplay. The game rewards strategic thinking, from deciding when to team up with others (and when to stab them in the back) to figuring out the best way to hunt or avoid the island‚Äôs mega-predators. The crafting system is deep, and the thrill of gathering materials to build your base and weapons while fending off enemy tribes is incredibly satisfying. If you‚Äôre into survival games with a high stakes, high tension environment where every decision counts‚Äîand where a single mistake could lead to an epic failure‚ÄîARK: The Survival of the Fittest is a must-try. It‚Äôs perfect for anyone who loves a challenge, epic dino battles, and the thrill of outlasting other players in a hostile environment. gets a little bit repetetive after an hour I would say, but it was definitely worth playing.

The game mechanics reminded me a little bit of Tetris but different. The goal is to combine small buildings to create even bigger buildings that can house more population (in this case the population is simply the score and has no other effect). You can see the next 4 buildings coming up - similar to the next block appearing in Tetris. However you are not under any time pressure, so you can plan ahead peacefully.

There are a few interesting twists by combining several buildings in a single turn which award you cards if you've done enough of them. In return those cards give you strong moves that would be otherwise impossible such as switching building positions for example. Without them your progress would be much more limited.

Graphics are solid, however I personally dont value graphics that much and completed the game without ever changing the standard building set. But there are several more to choose from to get some variety if you want to.

Achieved 100% after 5 hours, so the achievements are quite easy and fast to achieve. | Very satisfying tile matching gameplay. To me, it‚Äôs a mix of Bejeweled and Dorfromantik. I can see myself sinking a lot of time into this while listening to music, podcasts, audiobooks, or interviews. VR mode is a welcome and beautiful bonus. I love the art style and I‚Äôve only unlocked 2 themes out of maybe 8-10. | I've played this loads, it's an easy game to just run in the background when you're doing things and pick it back up when you have a few minutes. Ideal for working at home and in need of a break. 

The game itself is pretty easy to learn, but takes some time to get used to, certainly if you want to get far in the game. The challenge is to really grow your cities and take advantage of the board setup. 

Nice casual game that combines "city building" with a nice laid back puzzle game. | I played the demo before release and its still such a beautiful, peaceful game. For $6 dollars (and especially while its on sale for so cheap) I could not recommend this game enough. This game is a wonderful stress killer and its visuals and music really cement that fact.

10/10

The game sucks worse in every aspect than its predecessors. It looks worse and the amount of content in the game is behind pay walls, not skins but factions you can play and they want you to keep playing for what there isn't even any real cool looking items the game is frankly disgusting. Its agonising playing against AI as they have loaded dice and it takes so long for it to make a move. | Absolute deceptive marketing from Cyanide studios and thus I have refunded and will not play Blood Bowl 3. They have lost my business. Hoping that they fixed the problems with the game, I didn't even attempt to play a real match. Instead I went to see what teams I could play and noticed so many of them aren't there. Tracking them down I went to the in-game store. They have purposely hidden the additional costs you need to pay to play this game unlike in Blood Bowl 2. If you want to play as any additional non-launch team, you need to pay for them in-game. At the time of writing this, each team is minimum 750 warpstones (1000 for norse) for a total of 6250 warpstones. That comes to a WHOPPING 49.99 EUR if you buy the Warpstones in bulk. Also I do not use EUR so an additional 50 EUR is an insane steep price on-top of the box price for this game. 

For example Blood Bowl 2, lists on their store page the costs for the "DLC" (teams). It is not hidden in game, you can see before buying it what additional you may need to pay. ALSO Blood Bowl 2 has a game package that gives you all the teams. Besides the first box price I paid when BB2 first game out, I have never bought an additional team, each was given to me for free.

This is absolute deceptive marketing and despicable micro-transaction practices. Teams are not "Cosmetics" and you are locking game play via paid content you can only find out after you paid for the product. Cyanide good luck with BB4 cause you have destroyed your reputation / image with BB3. | If you buy the game now, you have already missed out on a significant number of teams. You can grind through the battle pass (or buy it) to get the newest one, but if you want any of the teams that were released before you bought this game, you need to buy them with in game premium currency. In BB2, at least the teams were separate DLC and you could wait until a sale to pick them up a bit cheaper. | Love Blood Bowl.  Fun to be able to try all of the teams and play in a low stress environment against AI (Which is terrible and easily beatable).  As an App it is quite unstable and there is a risk of losing hours of progress in the blink of an eye with random crashes every so often.  Overall, a good intro into the tabletop version of the game. | It's insane that it's 2025 and this doesn't allow in-game saves vs the AI when a game takes about an hour to play. Moreover, only meaningless exhibition games allow you to play without the timer.

Grown humans have dogs, wives, children, calls from work, and friends who call and say they're headed to the pub and you should come along. 

So take your downvote, incel developers, and continue to never sell the game except at a steep discount. There's a bunch of DLC I'd even buy if the game was playable for a functioning adult.

It combines a campaign map with turn based battles. You can create your own civilization with its ruler and heroes, and play as the fantasy (or steam-punk) civilization you always wanted.

But I have some bigger issues with this game:

First off, since the last big update, the game has a tendency to crash on the campaign map. Which is really annoying, but dealbreaker for me is, that it also corrupts saves, so you cannot continue where it crashed. Especially annoying when you just fought a big battle and then lose all your progress.

Second is, that yes - you can create different civs - but in the end, they all play very similar. You always want to rush your city cap and just build as many armies as possible. Build wide, claim as much territory as possible. That's the strategy. The only difference is how your units look and what tomes you unlock. To be fair, some of the final tomes are very unique, but it takes a very long time till you get there and most of the game is already over by that point.

Third, the campaign map itself. You notice it is randomly generated. It's a combination of biomes with some features in it and some randomly placed ancient wonders. Every map looks similar. Sometimes it has more forest and sometimes more sand, but in the end, there are no "unique" landmarks or sights. After a few games, you have seen everything. Which would be okay, but one of the key points of this game is to go out and explore the map... which is just not interesting.

When CoH3 launched I was thoroughly disappointed and disenfranchised. Especially as people made reviews of the game and showcased it's downward journey. But after picking it up on a free weekend, my prejudice was completely wrong. It turned out significantly better than expected.

I can thoroughly recommend giving the game a chance when it's on sale or going through a free weekend. Development is slow due to the small size of the team, but they're dedicated to making CoH3 better with each well put together patch. Each iteration will have its issues and that's to be expected. And if you're not enjoying the current patch, that's okay.

If you're not interested in PvP at all, the modding scene has many neat things to play around with against AI. It's especially fun with friends.

The critique against the campaign is fair though. CoH1 and 2's campaigns are significantly better. So if you enjoy what CoH3 has to offer, consider looking into the previous titles! And if you enjoy the style of RTS but not the game itself, consider CoH2. Same concept, but executed differently. Hence the divide and hate from CoH2 veterans

tl/dr, don't knock it till you try it. It's easy to absorb others' thoughts and opinions. This game is a lot like Rogue Tower, if rogue tower didn't suck. The balance needs some work but if they can work that out this is a helluva cool game. If you've played Rogue Tower you'll like this better.

Gameplay
Standard Tower defence with a twist, you pick a tower and a gem. The tower determines what the tower does, the gem determines all of the important characteristics. Any gem can go into any tower, but not all gems work well in all towers. The Rain tower for example doesn't work well with gems that only deal damage as it applies the full DOT but only does a tiny amount of damage. Once you've got towers set up you'll have to equip your towers or you won't make it far. What you get to equip them with is entirely up to RNG. 

Towers
There are six towers and six gems. 
There is also a Bomb, all you need to know about the bomb is that there is not, at time of writing, a pause button.

The Towers - All stats  vary wildly based on the gem in the tower, important information will be listed
Boulder - Lowest fire rate, highest damage, small AOE on impact, Low DPS, great tower for things that do things every X seconds. 
Firethrower - Moderate fire rate, moderate damage, Directed AOE hits all units in path, DPS suffers from the fact that this tower tracks enemies rather than firing in a set direction. 
Projectile - Highest Fire rate, moderate damage, good single target DPS. 
Lightning - Low fire rate, short range, less damage than the projectile tower, hits several targets within range for moderate damage
Rain - low damage, low fire rate, low range, creates a persistent AOE that deals damage to all units in an area
Spike Tower - Low fire rate, moderate damage, mid size AOE on impact, 
Bomb - There is no pause button
At level 10 each tower gets an upgrade, each tower levels up individually.

Gems
Arcane - Highest Fire rate, second lowest damage. Fire rate scales 20% better than normal, damage scales 10% worse.
Upgrades: Fire rate, crit damage, healing per wave, gold per wave, item generation, AOE per kill and a temporary fire rate buff per kill. 
Fire - Lowest damage, second highest fire rate, burn DOT. DOTs are 20% more effective, 10% less damage to slowed enemies.
Upgrades: DOT, dealing extra damage on the final burn tick, damage, enemy healing debuff, permanent burn increase per kill, increased burn on crits, gold generation per burn tick, and instant burn application once burn hits 1000.
Earth - Lowest fire rate, highest damage. 20% extra damage to armoured enemies, fire rate scales 20% worse than normal
Upgrades: Range, stunning crits damage to armoured enemies, stacking damage buff per wave, reduced crystal cost, stacking damage during combat buff, AOE bleed on kill, AOE on kill.
Poison - Moderate fire rate, moderate damage, Poison DOT. 5% increased damage per second in combat (up to 50) 15% reduced damage to burning enemies.
Upgrades: Damage to poisoned enemies, poison damage, tower exp on kill, poison spread on enemy death, inc poison on armoured enemies, AOE on kill.
Electric - High crit chance. 40% increased critical damage scaling, 10% reduced damage to armoured enemies.
Upgrades: Chance to double damage, chance to ignore armour, stacking crit damage boost per kill, crit damage, boost to damage fire rate and DOT (as a single upgrade), chance for gold/crit, AOE on kill, Chance for additional chain
Cold - Moderate damage, moderate fire rate, slow. Increased damage to slowed enemies, 50% reduced DOT.
Upgrades: Increased slow, increased damage to slowed enemies, crit chance, AOE on kill, freeze chance, Tower EXP per wave, chance for additional hits gold per kill. 

Issues
Balance
Ostensibly you need to use a variety of towers to achieve a win. In practice you max out the ice progression tree, spam projectile towers with ice gems and then just keep playing the next wave. Why? Because projectile towers offer the best DPS and ice gems gain experience every round which gets them to level 20 very quickly. Why does that matter? Two reasons, one levelling up makes your towers better, and two at level 20 your towers give all other towers of the same type an additional equipment slot (up to 20 slots total) and this lets you put in as many items as you'd like. On top of all of that it slows enemies.

Other
You can't remove towers once you've placed them. 

Conclusion
Overall I like this game and reccomend it if you like tower defence games. | If you are like me and love both Tower Defense and Roguelikes this is a must get. They combine the features of both genre perfectly. None of the elements are to deep yet intertwine well so you see progress each run. 

As a TD alone it is a fun game. Add in the roguelike elements and the fun doubles. | huge potential, developer still working on the updates, cant wait for more

Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | ‰∏éÂÖ∂ËØ¥ÊòØÂüéÂ∏ÇËê•ÈÄ†ÊàñËÄÖÂü∫Âú∞Âª∫ËÆæÔºåÊõ¥ÂÉèÊòØÊúâÈôêËµÑÊ∫êÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ∏∏ÊàèÔºå‰∏çÁ¨¶ÂêàÊàëÁöÑÂÖ¥Ë∂£

I think Terra Invicta is a perfect example of the all-too-common case of a game that simply tries to do too much.  The majority of successful games fall into at least one of three categories:

1.  Simple yet robust mechanics and artistic direction.
2.  Broad public appeal with serviceable game-play.
3.  In-depth simulations and a targeted niche market.

Terra Invicta is closest to the third, and yet seems to misunderstand its goal.  While I certainly can't speak on the developers' behalves, I can attest to the potential of this game's concepts.  Terra Invicta is primarily meant to be a game where politics, espionage, and warfare all mesh under the setting of a "plausible" alien infiltration of Earth.  There are certainly elements of all three in Terra Invicta, but then you have... ship construction?  Global Warming mechanics?  A bloated tech tree from hell?

These mechanics - while certainly interesting - detract from the essence of the game.  The game is a grand strategy, keyword grand.  You can't manage the individual economies of every nation on Earth while simultaneously committing espionage on your political opponents, all while fighting off aliens.  Well, you can, but then you run into the biggest problem of why doing too much in a single game ends up as a mess: time.

I played a single Terra Invicta run for about 65 hours and was not even a quarter of the way done with the game.  This is not a good thing; a game like this only holds the attention span of an individual for so long before they move onto something else for a while.  By spending so much time trying to connect so many different complex mechanics, each one fails to feel immersive, instead having a very gamey feel to it.

Other than that primary issue, there's also the assinine decision to blend turn-based and real-time onto the same strategic layer, making flexible management an utter nightmare.  Finally, there's a game direction change I'd make: Have nations be more hands-off, with subtle direction and especially allegiance being the player's main driving factor in the political sphere.  Unless you believe the world is run by "the cabal" or whatever, a gameplay loop that felt more like nudging nations rather than steering them outright would work wonders for immersion and interesting, replayable gameplay.

The best time I had in the game was in the early days of space warfare, where I basically partook in a pseudo-guerrilla war against the servants and protectorate, all while playing politics down on Earth, fighting a proxy war against the Academy for several African nations.  Overall, I can't recommend the game, but that's not to say there's no fun to be had here, or even that you will find the game as lackluster as I did. | A cool concept which breaks under the immense pressure of its many, MANY, parts. 

Everything I would want to critique can be summed by pointing out that less than 10 % of players have the 'Endgame' achievement, which basically gives you your faction victory condition. Only the victory CONDITION mind you, there's still 50 % of game to go at that point.

Like the transfer from Earth to Jupiter, this game is a SLOW burn. Blending real time and turn based while having to manage multiple layers of gameplay turns into a never ending cycle of interruption and slows things down tremendously by the midgame. Actually learning the game is obtuse and hard. You could learn everything about the already somewhat complex (and underexplained) earth layer and then be curbstomped by the additional amount of information you need to know to get a grasp on the economy, combat and strategy layer of space on top of it all. Naturally you need to manage both at the same time, yet one is half-turn based, as mentioned.

Ship building and the resulting space combat is as hard and obtuse as the strategic layers. Learning about the dozens of weapons, weapon types and multiple hundreds of techs makes preparing a fleet to fight with a chore. Its true that you are fighting an Alien adversary, and admitedly the initial horror of the unknown does have an impact, but his quickly turns into the ACTUAL horror of the unknown gameplay mechanics, as you realize that the game gives no guidance or help when it comes to fighting the Ayyys. 

Fission or Fusion? Laser or Phaser? Want your gun coiled or uncoiled? My ship just got zapped from 1000m, what exactly did I do wrong? Who the hell knows. Here's some councillor tasks to distribute before you go on youtube and learn what the multiple Excel spreadsheets worth of stats mean.

Terra Invicta is a rare case. The sum of its parts is less than what one would probably find if the spaghetti of mechanics and gameplay layers were to be untangled. Its an ambitious project that certainly has it's fans and enthusiasts, but I would argue this gets carried more by the premise of realistic sci-fi √† la Expanse than the game design itself. 

Only recommended for the truely dedicated Sci-Fi lovers and people who love learning a lot of mechanics. But even then, just like 90 % of the playerbase before you, you will most likely run out of Œîv before reaching the endgame anyway. | Âª∫ËÆÆÂá∫‰∏™‰ª•ÂõΩÂÆ∂‰∏∫‰∏ª‰ΩìÊ¥æÂà´‰∏∫ËæÖÁöÑÊ®°ÂºèÔºåÂõΩÂÆ∂‰∏éÂõΩÂÆ∂‰πãÈó¥Ë∞àÂà§„ÄÅÂêà‰Ωú„ÄÅÁ£®Êì¶Á≠â„ÄÇÂ§ñÊòü‰πüÊãÜÂºÄÂàÜ‰∏∫Ê¥æÂà´ÔºåËøôÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÂõΩÂÆ∂Ë∫´‰ªΩ‰∏éÂ§ñÊòüÊ¥æÂà´ËøõË°åÂêà‰Ωú‰∏éÂÖ∂ÂÆÉÊ¥æÂà´ÂØπÊäóÔºåÊúõÈááÁ∫≥ÔºÅ

Some people also consider it to be two separate games but that's incorrect. It's a fusion of genres which interconnect in ways that allow longterm strategies to play over a *very* long normal speed campaign and still quite some time for an accelerated campaign.
It's basically a newtonian physics enabled solar system simulator with an added geopolitical game on earth. If you enjoy slowly building a shadow empire with one of seven different goals, depending on the faction, which eventually progresses to colonizing the solar system and building fleets of ships (which have battles using newtonian physics) then this game is for you. | Even in its current early access state this game is very close to being a masterpiece. But once you figure it out, this game provides you with a feeling of fulfilment I havent had in a while. Highly recommend even in its current state.

A Love Letter to the Ninth Art ‚Äì A Middle-Aged Player's 100-Hour Journey Through Baldur's Gate 3

As someone nearing forty, with both elderly parents and young children to care for, finding large chunks of time to sit in front of a computer and savor a game is no easy feat. This Spring Festival, I made up my mind to finally taste this cup of coffee that had been brewing for years. With the understanding and support of my wife (for which I am deeply grateful), I managed to carve out a week to indulge in uninterrupted play. After 99 hours and 40 minutes, I completed the game. Sitting in front of the screen late at night, I was left in awe, unable to shake the profound impact it had on me. This journey will undoubtedly remain one of the most unforgettable experiences of my life, a radiant milestone in my personal gaming history.

What Larian has created here is far from an ordinary video game.

As a game, every design element is seamlessly integrated, perfectly balanced. The freedom it offers is almost overwhelming‚Äîyou can truly be yourself. The equipment, levels, and stats are meticulously crafted, catering to a broad spectrum of players.

As music, Down by the River drifts with the breeze, becoming a flowing narrative. I Want to Live tears at your soul during moments of decision, and The Power resonates as you grasp the prism in victory. Each theme song fits its scene so perfectly that it transcends the medium, transforming into an interactive symphonic poem that I found myself revisiting and reflecting on long after the game had ended.

As a novel, the content itself is a masterful piece of fantasy literature. The writers clearly possess the skill to craft a best-selling fantasy novel. Themes of justice versus evil, life versus death, and killing versus sparing provoke deep philosophical reflection. If watching a movie in a theater is like spending 2.5 hours appreciating a thought-provoking film, then Baldur's Gate 3 is like spending over 100 hours living a tumultuous, magical life filled with difficult choices and moral dilemmas.

I named my final save file in the camp, where I chatted with everyone before the end, "Do Not Want to Say Farewell." After journeying together, sharing both hardships and triumphs with these friends and comrades, I truly wished we could continue living together. I exhausted every dialogue option in the camp, searching for more interactions, especially with Shadowheart, whose seven or eight hugs still lingered with the warmth of data. I couldn‚Äôt bear to say goodbye. Yet, Larian, in their cruel yet merciful way, allowed each companion to move forward with their scars‚Äîsome destined to carry the stars on their shoulders, others to return to the mundane life of hearth and home. This, perhaps, is the most tender form of realism: all encounters must eventually be returned to the passage of time.

Thus, my Dungeons & Dragons tale has been sealed in the evening breeze of the Sword Coast. In this lifetime, I will return to experience the lives of Astarion and other characters. Perhaps this is the greatness of CRPGs: they allow us, in the crevices of our real lives, to live countless versions of ourselves we never had the chance to be.

While there are some criticisms and suggestions for improvement regarding BG3, they are minor blemishes on an otherwise flawless gem. Some aspects could indeed be tweaked for player convenience, while others are subjective preferences rather than flaws.

Once you‚Äôve spent 10-15 hours learning the game‚Äôs mechanics and fundamental principles, crossing that threshold, you can‚Äôt help but marvel at how Larian managed to create such a masterpiece. If this work remains unrivaled, it‚Äôs because it is truly exquisite and deserves to be cherished. If it is ever surpassed, then another jewel will have been added to the annals of gaming history, another gift for us all.

Thank you, Larian. | The replayability of this game is insane, Larian did an amazing job giving us exactly what we wanted and maybe even a little more. This game has taken over my life and I love it so much, lol, and showing no signs of putting it down any time soon! | This is probably going to be one of the best games for the next decade, the voice acting is sublime and the writers seemed to have made deals with the devil in order to make such a good tale. 10/10 | I started playing this game a year and a few months after it was launched and immediately got into character creation which took me over an hour not to mention building my Dream Guardian. Since purchasing it at full price, I was weary to buy a game for 60 bucks, but it has been the best 60 bucks I've spent in a LONG time. 

The whole game itself doesn't hold your hand during the game, but it does help you build up your skills and learn how to play as you go which is great for those who haven't played CRPG turn based game before. I have basically played this nonstop since October to pass time and as you can see with my 527 hours on record, I absolutely LOVE this game. The options for responses and endings are endless. I'm thoroughly blown away with the voice acting and, yes, the mod options. There are many people who hate playing with mods, but to me it adds a lot to the game and enhances my game play experience making me want to play it more. I have done numerous campaigns and as of January 2025, I'm doing my 2nd durge campaign trying to play a somewhat evil character which is hard as I've cried from being evil to pixels haha. 

Overall, I think this game may be the best game I've ever played and I love how Larian and the VA's show their active participation in the community along with Larian giving us FREE updates and gives modders the toolkit. This company could've charged $100 or more for this game with the amount of work and thought put into it along with the (again) FREE updates, but they didn't. They have shown they care more for the player's experience and making a game that out beats other new games and certain *ahem developers AHEM Bethesda* by giving us a game that is completed at release (from what I've been told by other gamers who played this at release). I recommend this game to anyone who wants a rich, fulfilling game that doesn't have any extra catches outside the initial price. | I have played this game for 6 hours (2h on character creator), never played this type of game before.. can say I am impressed and enjoying it a lot.

18 hours in the game: I think that I'm addicted. The stories are surprising and wholesome. I feel like a hero in this game, living for the good of the people.

50 hours: I finally finished act 1. And oh boy did I turn from good to evil with every step I took. I didn't mean to be... How was I supposed to know that pulling the wrong lever, I'll be catapulting a gnome to space. That wasn't my fault.

80 hours: Yes! Give me your gold. All the shiny trinkets you have. Give me your soul and all the power you hold. Give me more... MORE!

100 hours: How dare you look down on me, thinking like you could ever defeat me?! Hit me with all you got, it will never be enough!

120 hours: ... *only screams echo in the darkness* ...

130 hours: *Muahahaha-*
You may call me the blood queen,
but your agenda is also driven by greed.
The battle you lost, your advisors lied.
Your heroes are dead, your city is mine.
No evil as dark or vengeance as red,
have never been seen as I took the kings head.

My issue lies with the developers itself; the games "rules" and restrictions for servers are not on the game itself it is all run via a discord server where the discord mods are... discord mods. Never have I known a game to have it's integrity held together by a discord server ran by moderators where all the rules for the game are found. Most of us have discord these days but even still; it feels... tacky. 

In addition to how the game is managed there is a problem with russian cheaters; you can provide all the evidence in a discord ticket and you will more than likely be ignored. In add, brilliant game; poor management. | It's fun, and there should be more quality of life updates. There are too few interiors now.

I say yes because it is a good game but there are just some really dumb things. Here are 6 dumb things i found whilst playing the game.
1. There are way to many visitors in the park in early game. You open your park with ONE attraction and there's  900+ people spawning. That's way too much.
2. Despite having so much visitors, your rides barely have more than 20 people in queue. "Waiting queue is too long" bro its less than 3 mins. its just full of visitors walking up and down in my valley and colliding with each other.
3. Pathfinding is HORRENDOUS. I created a large entrance path in my park, more than 20 metres large. There are half the people that take the EXACT same line.
4. Opening a ride grabs all of your visitors, its just dumb. Its like a super powerful magnet.
5. Prices are stupid. They're ready to pay 35$ for some rides but not 0.5$ for karting? If its not free they wont go on the ride instead they will just do a u-turn and walk away from it.
6. The way technicians work is totally useless. It seems Fronteir spent some time developing plannings, but its useless? If i assign a technician to a ride, then why is he not repairing it during their shift and why do i have to call someone else? And why is he at the opposite side of my park + Its beyond stupid to have to wait until its too late for a technician to fix it. If i assign a technician to a ride, he should be around it for all their shift and checking it multiple during their shift. But no, they wait util its broken. Clowns.
It is a good game after all and i do enjoy playing it but i feel like they didn't test the game before publishing it. What i think they need to do is a huge update just fixing all the bugs and dumb things that there are.
Good game though. | A half-assed sequel to a pretty good game. The idea of planet coaster 2 was great and had me pumped for it, but it was a huge disappointment. There used to be a time when a game would be released in it's 1.0 foundational state, and it was fundamentally considered [i]complete[/i]. It meant that all the gameplay and story elements were in place, and any ancillary content could be added in at a future date. 
This could include extra story elements, items, dungeons, expansions, patches, and DLC etc.

Apparently, not anymore.

I waited for years to see Last Epoch exit early access and finally hit that glorious 1.0 release.
I even waited another year for the game to have all the creases ironed out.

So, I purchased the game, and was having a decent time. 
...that is, until the main quest storyline just 'stopped'.
Now to be clear, I don't mean it [i]concluded[/i]. I mean, it just 'stops' half-way through the story, and then you're left to go do mindless end-game farming. 
I genuinely thought my game was bugged and that the main quest wasn't showing. But a bit of research had me find out that the devs didn't think to complete the most basic element of a game - the story, before a 1.0 launch.

And what's worse, is that people just defend this type of practise?

Imagine if I sold you a book, but left the back half completely blank, and I told you "I'll write the rest some time in the future. Not really sure when though"
Not a sequel, but I'll finish the first book at some indeterminate time in the future.
Nebulous much?

Or imagine you sit down at a restaurant, and the waiter brings you only half of your meal, and says "We only made the first half - even though you paid for all of it. We'll eventually cook you the second half, at some point. Just not today. But you can have dessert! We have loads of dessert!"
Ludicrous. And yet, that's the standard that is being accepted more and more nowadays.

Sure, Last Epoch has some great elements to it. Genuinely.
Character building is cool. Loot filters in the game are top-notch. Visuals can be great.
But presentation means little when the foundational product is incomplete - [b]at full price[/b].

Ridiculous. 
Truthfully, I feel cheated. And looking at the 2025 road-map, where story content will be added 'some time later', I realise I should've just waited until the far off future when the game price will have likely dropped. 
Cheaper price for an 'actual' finished product.

This just feels like a lazy rush-to-market strategy, and I'd refund if I could, however it took me way more than the allotted refund time to know that the story would just 'cut off'. Which seems scummy.

Also, apparently even one of the game devs thinks you're being too unreasonable in expecting a 1.0 full release of a game to be, y'know, [i]'fully completed'[/i]. As he said that the 1.0 distinction of the game is "Fairly Arbitrary".
I call major bs on that one. 
You don't get to redefine what "Full Release" means, just to account for your lack of complete content. 

Furthermore, the endgame content, while nice in theory, honestly just boils down to this:

- Click a big floaty island in space.
- Now click on a smaller floaty island in space and fight a bunch of enemies.
- Do 10-20 more of these smaller floaty islands - with the same grinding of enemies.
- Now you've unlocked a boss fight.
- Fight said boss
- Click another big floaty island in space and repeat.

It's boring, and in no way a good placeholder for a completed and memorable story.

If the game was completed, I would've looked back on the game and thought "Yeah wow. That was a nice experience. Not [i]the best I've ever played[/i], but nice. And that's worth a recommend."

As it stands, I think you should stay away from the game for another year (or possibly two) - as of this review date, and reassess the state of the game at that time.

Until then, don't perpetuate crappy business standards - or they'll become normalised and you'll be the only one paying for it. | Á¶ªÁ∫øÊ®°ÂºèË¶ÅËÅîÁΩëÁé©ÔºåËÅîÊú∫‰ΩìÈ™åÊûÅÂ∑ÆÔºåÊú™ÂÖ•ÊâãÁöÑÂª∫ËÆÆÂÖàÁúãÁúãËßÜÈ¢ëÂíåËØÑÊµãËßÇÊúõ„ÄÇ | The game isn't fun. This is a combination of skills that feel unimpactful, low monster density, overall slow game pace, low difficulty, and an endgame that encourages you to just rush through to the objective as fast as you can rather than kill anything, among other reasons.

Most of the praise around this game will be about "potential" rather than what's actually there. If you've played or followed this game since the beta you should know that the developers have done absolutely nothing to demonstrate they can ever deliver on this potential. What's actually implemented is very bare-bones, often buggy, and not fun/interesting. Will the game be good eventually? Maybe, but unlikely. And should you spend money on a game that isn't good right now? Absolutely not.

It was more casual than poe but not too casual like d3, grind end game gear need min max crafting which make it not too boring. 10/10 | perfect to play while you wait for poe2 updates :P
and it is better than diablo 4

I really want to like this game. It has the best building system I've ever encountered and the professions are varied with plenty of unlockable content. However, that's where the good stops.

They added timers to crafting. This isn't a deal breaker in itself. Plenty of survival games add timers. But these are mobile game timers. For example, you need 100 charcoal to make bronze. You get 25 charcoal every 20 minutes. So that's 80 minutes of waiting to get the charcoal. Then it takes 15 minutes to make the bronze ingots. So that's 95 minutes of work (1 hour and 25 minutes) just to get a basic material. It's insane. 

Resource placement also needs a look over. Basic materials like tin end up right next to high leveled enemies which are impossible for you to defeat. Devs say the goal is to cooperate with others but the player base just isn't there. I've also seen ore nodes spawn in mid air and lots of materials like to spawn hanging on the side of mountains. 

Inventory management is another issue. You need so many materials to do anything and most of them have stack sizes of 25 or 50. You might think this is enough but it takes 50 wood just to make one order or charcoal. My house is basically a giant mountain of chests to store things at this point. There is just a major disconnect between how much chests store and the materials they require for recipes or leveling professions (i won't even touch on the ridiculousness in that as many other reviews already do).

I do not recommend this game at this time. The most pressing thing is the punishing timers on crafting and the sheer impossibility of inventory management. If these two things get fixed, then I'd change to recommended even with the other issues. | There is nothing on the store page saying that when they release the full game you have to purchase it again and pay monthly. (you have to go to other website to find out) hell no, i want my money back! Lot of money to drop on a game and DLC for an early access and you don't even get to keep it. Spielerlebnis was f√ºr ein Spielerlebnis - wozu weitermachen, warum mind. 3h Material Farmen von dem man Unmengen braucht und wegschmei√üen darf so viele Kisten kann man nicht Bauen (Nachjustierung dringend erforderlich) - es gibt nichts was dich noch packt oder anregt weiterzuspielen.

Das Bauen macht richtig viel Spa√ü. Man hat die M√∂glichkeit, sehr sch√∂ne und kreative Geb√§ude zu entwerfen, was f√ºr Bau-Fans ein echtes Highlight ist. Das Kampfsystem ist noch nicht ganz ausgereift, aber es funktioniert bereits gut und bietet eine solide Grundlage.

Ein wichtiger Punkt, den man betonen sollte, ist, dass Pax Dei ein Spiel f√ºr Gruppen ist. Das bedeutet jedoch nicht, dass Solo-Spieler keinen Spa√ü haben k√∂nnen. Es dauert lediglich etwas l√§nger, wenn man alleine baut und Fortschritte erzielt.

Much better beginner experience in this one.. the super simple license test or whatever being a great intro to the concepts which then left me eager to start on hard to really scratch the brain itch.

The game is that perfect brain teaser in a visually pleasing package.. you look at a new shape and freak out at all the steps involved, then you design a factory that ends up being way more compact and efficient than you ever thought *feels good* and once that's delivered, you get introduced to the next layer of complexity. 

Still very early on in the game, but looking forwards to just how crazy it sends me in the best way.

Developers are completely out of touch, servers as unstable as the Somalian economy. They make promises they never keep or if they keep them its years after they said they would do it. Really wish I could recommend it but I can't. | As fun as the gameplay is, that's like literally the only compliment i can give it outside of the game looking beautiful, it's a sadistic grindfest that is so unbelievably overwhelming for any player, i have 200 hours and i still have zero clue what im doing because i am being constantly bombarded with new items and systems that by the time i get a grasp on one thing, i have to learn 5 more new things. | I didn't really doing anything in the first 6 hours and ended up with a full inventory of stuff... just stuff. The combat early on seems pointless as you can be surrounded by 20 mobs and take no damage. The graphics in the game are quirky with a ton of lighting issues making the game look awful most of the time. The user interface is horrid with overlays overlaying other overlays upon more overlays... it's a mess visually. Why would I want to get notified of other players failing crafting when I am just starting the game? It's a UX/UI designers nightmare. Early story and quests are meh. If I were to summarize my new experience, I wouldn't say it was "bad", I would say it's "a turn off". | Black Desert Online has one of the best early and mid-game experiences. Progress feels rewarding, the world is vast and fun to explore, and there's a real sense of discovery. However, the late game is a completely different story.

Once you hit the late-game grind, progression slows down dramatically, taking anywhere from 20 to 100 hours just to see any improvement. Season characters are a great addition, but they also remove the early game entirely by handing out free PEN gear, which can feel like skipping one of the best parts of the game.

The biggest issue is how demanding the late game is, both in time and money. The game leans heavily into pay-to-win mechanics‚Äîyou can buy Crons, making enhancement much less painful for those willing to spend money. While Black Desert has an incredible combat system and PvP is amazing, there's just not enough meaningful PvP content in the open world.

Overall, Black Desert isn‚Äôt a terrible game, but the late-game grind and monetization model make it hard to recommend unless you're ready to sink an absurd amount of time (or money) into it.

Genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Early Access

Mit 50 Jahren noch ein Spiel zu entdecken, das einen fesselt, motiviert, zum √úberlegen anregt und einfach begeistert , ist wirklich sch√∂n - DANKE DAF√úR! | Please fix the crash that results in a total hardware reset. The game is great, but currently unplayable for those that don't wish to damage their computers. | This is a really good game. I'm a newcomer to PoE, having only briefly tried the first game a few years back. I consider myself a fairly casual ARPG player, but I love RPGs in general. This game is very much worth the cost of admission.

This game's combat feels satisfying in a way that no other modern ARPG has quite managed for me. The character progression and build variety have been the real highlights, though. The various systems for managing skills, stats and gear are really enjoyable and easily understandable. The best part is you'll actually have to use these systems since the game isn't afraid to provide a challenge.

The amount of mechanical depth on offer here is really impressive for how intuitive everything is at a glance, you can tell the devs really put a great amount of thought and care into how everything is presented. There are some rough edges, but overall the game is really good in this regard.

I strongly dislike using guides, so I've gone in as blind as possible. I highly recommend taking this approach, despite what some players might say. Using a guide is not necessary, and overpowered builds will likely get nerfed. If you use a guide you are doing yourself a genuine disservice and ignoring the most interesting aspects of the game. That's just my two cents though, play the game however you like.

I don't have many complaints. I think endgame would be more fun if the player could return to an area after dying. The XP loss is a good mechanic in my opinion, but I don't like having to restart from scratch AND use another waystone in order to do so. It's tedious and requires too much attention. The game currently doesn't attempt to accommodate more casual players at endgame. I think more options and a less restrictive structure would help a lot. As it stands now, the campaign is the most enjoyable part of the game.
